items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Tides remain high for tonight's tide. Forecast high water is 21:30 on 08/10/21 with a level of 7.44 mAOD and a Force 1 Easterly wind. Tomorrow morning’s tide is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by midday, Saturday 09/10/2021.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 17:45 on 09/10/21 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 35 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 10/10/21, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible over the high tide on Friday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 8:13pm on Friday, but times of high water will vary slightly along the coast. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Impacts include minor flooding of roads and the possibility of some spray overtopping, but is not expected to result in property flooding. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. For those that use detailed tide information - the forecast high tide level at  Ilfracombe is 5.16 mAOD.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. With drier and more settled weather now forecast lake levels will slowly fall. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not expected.  High tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 5:15pm this afternoon (08/10/21). The river may over top banks and flood low lying land and footpaths. The predicted height of the tide is 4.95 - 5.15 metres.  The following high tide is expected at 5:45am.  The predicted height of the tide is 4.82 - 5.02 metres.  Based on recent forecasts it is likely that both tides will be towards the lower end of the ranges.  We continue to closely monitor the forecast and tide heights. Astronomical spring tides are peaking on Saturday (09/10/21) and fluvial levels are now falling slowly.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning (09/10/21).

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and for tomorrow’s high spring tides. High water at Truro is at 6.57pm tonight (Thursday 07 October).  High tides for tomorrow (Friday 08 October), are at  7.20am and 7.38pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Force 4 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast, and may cause minor wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas.   

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 2.88 mAOD, this is 0.03 metres below astronomical tide level. 

From Saturday onwards the tide levels begin to decrease. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update on Saturday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 02:00 AM on 09/10/2021. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge between 02:30 AM and 03:00 AM on 09/10/2021. We do not expect to see similar impacts for subsequent high tides. The weather is forecast to be largely calm with light winds and high pressure which is limiting tidal surge.  No significant rain is forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We will remove this message by 04:00 PM on 09/10/2021.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: Although high spring tides remain until Monday morning, these will not reach Flood Alert level.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. The period of high spring tides continues for the next few days.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. The period of high spring tides continues for the next few days.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Coastal conditions for the Wye estuary should ease for the 09/10/2021 high tide at 10:00am this morning.    
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
